bug.short_desc: [model] NPE while computing method unique key

long_desc.thetext: The attached code sample has ambiguous javadoc - it's not clear which of the getMax variants the link should be resolved to. Eclipse 3.3M3 correctly identifies the ambiguity, but doesn't have a hint other than removing the link. If it's not resolvable perhaps it should suggest converting it into {@code}? Also the javadoc spec seems to imply that getMax(Iterable ip1) should be more resolvable than getMax(Iterable) - so the 3rd instance shouldn't be ambiguous.
Created an attachment (id=54429) Snippet that produces the problem
Created an attachment (id=54430) Snippet that produces the problem
The JDK documentation sucks for this sort of stuff - otherwise I'd point to what it should be suggesting

Must be a problem in code select over the Java doc link. When I hover of the link I gte the folloing exception:
Exception in thread "Text Viewer Hover Presenter" java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.lookup.MethodBinding.computeUniqueKey(MethodBinding.java:328) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.lookup.Binding.computeUniqueKey(Binding.java:55) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.codeassist.SelectionEngine.selectFrom(SelectionEngine.java:892) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.codeassist.SelectionEngine.select(SelectionEngine.java:690) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.Openable.codeSelect(Openable.java:155) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.CompilationUnit.codeSelect(CompilationUnit.java:329) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.CompilationUnit.codeSelect(CompilationUnit.java:323) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.java.hover.AbstractJavaEditorTextHover.getHoverInfo(AbstractJavaEditorTextHover.java:120) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.java.hover.BestMatchHover.getHoverInfo(BestMatchHover.java:102) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.java.hover.JavaEditorTextHoverProxy.getHoverInfo(JavaEditorTextHoverProxy.java:69) at org.eclipse.jface.text.TextViewerHoverManager$4.run(TextViewerHoverManager.java:160)

The reason is that the @link #getMax(Iterable) is ambiguous. The javadoc tool doesn't detect it and creates two identical anchors for both methods. We have two ways to fix it. 1) The code selection checks if the binding is a valid binding before trying to open the javadoc. This would end up with no hints for this link. 2) We try to take the closest match if one is set for the problem method.
David, I'll let you investigate it.
This is a side effect of fix for bug 155003 to have the method thrown exceptions dumped in unique key... I'll add a check to prevent the NPE...
Created an attachment (id=54494) Proposed patch

Released for 3.3 M4 in HEAD stream.
Note for verifier, you need to use build I20061121-1845 to verify that this NPE really happens. As it was (unfortunately) introduced while fixing bug 155003, it does not happen in 3.3 M3...
We should also investigate why code selection is trying to get the key of a problem method binding. In this case the method is ambiguous. David, please comment on this.

Code select return java element as result. These java elements are computed from bindings. Code select can compute the elements from problems bindings for some specific case. Keys are used to build resolved java elements (e.g. ResolvedSourceMethod).
The current test case must be supported but the behavior of code select with ambiguous methods isn't perfect and must be improved. I opened another bug for this issue: bug 165900.
I close this bug as fixed because the NPE is fixed.
Verified for 3.3M4 with I20061212-0010.

bug.short_desc: [quick fix] Better suggestion needed for suppressing this warning.

long_desc.thetext:
In the attached code snippet you get a warning because a generic array of a parent type is created. The suggested fix is to suppress warnings for the whole method - whereas the best suggestion is to suppress warnings on the variable it's being assigned to.
This is the error Severity and Description Path Resource Location Creation Time Id Type safety : A generic array of Collection<Number> is created for a varargs parameter . Annoying.java line 30 1164311558082 6062

Created an attachment (id=54432) Code snippet that gets bad suggestion
Ideally it should suggest @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") on yy not the method.

Adding the SuppressWarning to the variable would work as the suppress also works on the initialzier, but we believe it should be discourraged to do so. Modifiers on a variable declaration should be for the variable itself, not for the initializer. When you split the variable assignement you will see the problem again.

bug.short_desc: Ensure that publish is done before bringing up the JSP

long_desc.thetext:
Driver: WTP 1.5.2 base
When creating Web services with clients and test with sample JSP on certain Web service runtime and certain servers, sometimes, the sample JSP would not come up and I got the error saying "Resource not available". When that happens, I often noticed the bottom-right corner of the workbench indicating that a publishing job is still in progress. If I wait until the publishing is done and refresh the URL to the JSP, the JSP would come up properly.
We've hit this problem so many times since the inception of our tools that we would like to discuss a couple ideas for bullet proofing WTP.
Kathy, assigned back to you for further investigation.
As noted, this is an old issue and easily worked around, therefore, deferred from the 1.5.x service stream to 2.0.
Gil, would you please take this over from Kathy given this is in JSP gen territory?
Target cleared. We haven't had bandwidth to investigate this in WTP 2.0. We'll reassess for WTP 3.0.

There has been alot of change that has gone into the test engine since this was opened last year. I just did some research on this subject and we check with server tools to insure the publish has been done at the right place. Kathy was with me the day we looked over the code and everything looked good at that time.
*** Bug 201918 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I asked the server tooling team. They checked the WTP API and indicated that we can use the API IServer.addPublishListener() to listen to publish start and finish on a server.
So we should try to use that API to ensure that publish is done before bringing up the JSP. We are currently just checking if the server needs to be published and send off a request if it does. However, we are not able to guarantee that the publish is done before the JSP is displayed.
We should put a safty switch (of only waiting for a pre-determined among of time) when waiting for the publish to finish in case the server does not have autopublish on. When that's the case, a warning should be issued to ask the user to do a manual publish before bringing up the JSP manually.
This problem seems to creep up once in a while depending on the machine and the server. Let's try to address this in WTP 2.0.2 before it becomes a problem again.
Defering to WTP 3.0 M3.

bug.short_desc: [Workbench] Workbench should check for existing display before creating one

long_desc.thetext: Created an attachment (id=55157) proposed patch

I doubt you are able to create the display with debug options without recreating the Policy logic somewhere down below. I'm not sure what we should do about this. Maybe we could get SWT to give us API to activate debugging/tracing after the display has been created?

I think it comes down to the question of how are we getting the splash bundle activated. There are 2 options here: 1) The splash bundle is on the osgi.bundles list. With a start level of 1, we can get progress before update.configurator runs which is interesting, however this requires swt on the bundles list and a platform-dependent config.ini. In this case we wouldn't really know what debug options to use.
2) The splash bundle is not on the osgi.bundles list, it is lazy-started and the application creates it. The progress starts at the same time as it did before, and since the application is creating the splash bundle, it could choose to create the display first, or pass to the splash bundle which debug options to use.
Not for M4. Too risky.

Given that our splash implementation will be created with the workbench leaving things as it is seems fine. If an eager splash creates the display it can be responsible for providing the correct debug info. We can simply document this requirement. I'm checking in the patch.
Verified in source in I20070206-0010

bug.short_desc: Console fails to open at workbench (for two specific laptops) during remote profiling

long_desc.thetext:
The problem was detected using the TPTP-4.3.0-200611160100A workbench and RAC.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Install RAC on LinuxIA32 or OS/400 machine 2. Start the RAC 3. Profile a simple external java application from the client workbench (on Windows XP)
Problem: When remotely profiling a simple external java application from a workbench, the console fails to open on the workbench but some initial data is collected and shown in the data views. This only occurs on some latops.
This is similar to bug 159938 (which has been fixed) but now the problem is more limited. It only shows up when running the workbench on certain laptops but not others and not on any of the desktops tried (although it occurs everytime on the laptops on which it does occur). So far it occurs when running the workbench on two specific IBM T30 laptops (which contain Intel Pentium 4M cpu's and multiple NICs) but not on a T41 or other IBM laptops. The problem occurs with a variety of servers (including OS400 and Linux IA32). It occurs with a variety of JDKs on the client (tried IBM 1.5.0 SR3 and Sun 1.5.0_04-b05).
Because of the restricted set of machines encountering the problem, I am settting severity at major rather than critical.
This problem has been discussed with Samson.

Bob, is this concidered a regression? Can you also add the committers and Joanna if appropriate that are affected by this to the defect since it is a US holiday. We need to triage this asap to determine if it is stop ship for 4.3

This is not a 4.3 regression but it may be a leftover of a possible 4.2.1 regression that Samson fixed there (bug 159938). If so, it is a very limited leftover (see below). There was a web of bugs involved as far as I can tell (including various dups and a related bug 158091) leading back possibly/circumstantially to bug 105824. Samson can better explain if needed as he is the one who sorted thru it and made the fix.
My own opinion is that this is not a stop ship and should be targeted to 4.4 because it only affects two specific laptops and is not reproducible by anyone else. I set severity below critical for that reason. I have updated the summary to clarify that (details in comment #1) and have cc'ed Samson.
This is actually found in the 4.3 driver but is not a stop-ship (only reproducible on two laptops of the same model). Therefore we will revisit this in 4.4.
Retarget to future due to resource limitation.

Dup of bug 158091.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 158091 ***
Update target to match the iteration when this defect was processed

bug.short_desc: WSDL import cannot use relative import with to parent directories

long_desc.thetext:
When going through a skeleton or client scenario with a WSDL file, if that root WSDL file has relative import with "../" to parent directories, the CopyWSDLCommand will put the imported WSDL/XSD files outside the WEB-INF or Web Content directory.
We currently have a limitation saying that:
WSDL import statement can only have absolute URLs or relative URLs in the same directory. For example, relative import in the following form is not supported: <import namespace="http://someNamespace/" location="../someFile.wsdl"/>
The workaround is to move the root WSDL file to the top of the directory. That is, the WSDL and XSD files imported by the root WSDL file needs to be a child of the root WSDL file rather than its parent.
To fix this problem, we would have to walk the entire tree of import and have CopyWSDLCommand copy from the top that tree. We would then have to pass the information of where the root WSDL file is relative the top of the tree to the Web service runtime so that they could update deployment specific information if necessary. However, we need to verify that the various Web service runtime can handle WSDL files not at the top of the WSDL/XSD tree.
Another option is to copy the root WSDL file to the top of the WSDL/XSD tree and update the import of that file pointing down to its children.
*** Bug 165722 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Targetted (tentatively) to WTP 1.5.3.
Andrew, could you please take a look at this? Thanks!

Created an attachment (id=57104) Patch for axis.create.ui and consumption plugins
Here is a proposed patch, please give it a try.

This patch is adding a new CopyWSDLTreeCommand. This command is similar to the CopyWSDLCommand which is currently used, with the additional step of calculating the shortest common directory path of the wsdl and all its imports and using that path as the "root" of the copy (i.e. it will copy the whole tree structure rooted at that path to the target directory). The new relative path of the wsdl can be retrieved from this command after the copying is done.
bug 171064 open to track changes required for WTP 2.0.

Patch reviewed, tested and committed to R1_5_maintenance and HEAD. It has also been released to R1_5_maintenance for WTP 1.5.3 as v200701191623. It will be released to HEAD after the weekly WTP 2.0 integration build is declared later on today.
Bug 171071 has been opened to make this copy WSDL algorithm into a public utility method in WTP 2.0.
BTW, I've dup 171064 to 171071.
Released to HEAD as v200701191645.
Verified on WTP 1.5.3 20070125 driver. Closing.

This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP bugs which are in the resolved state without an appropriate targeted version. If you feel this bug was closed inappropriately, please reopen.

bug.short_desc: WSDL/XSD files not copied when import URL with relative imports are to

long_desc.thetext:
When going through skeleton or client scenario, if there are many levels of relative imports, some WSDL/XSD files might not copied.
This is due to the URI path being too long and the code is unable to open a URL connection to the imported XSD file.
The fix is to normalize the URI to resolve the relative imports before trying to open them.
Targetting 1.5.3.
Created an attachment (id=55289) Patch for 165723 and 165725

Using a simplier algorithm to resolve "/.." rather than calling the normalize function on an encoded URI since we would have problem parsing an encoded URI if there's special characters such as space in the workspace path.
Patch reviewed by Peter. Checked into R1_5_maintenance and HEAD. Will release later on today.
Released to HEAD and R1_5_maintenance.
Verified on WTP 1.5.3 20070125 driver. Closing.

bug.short_desc: Home button is not available in Method invocation view.

long_desc.thetext:
Home [reset scale] button is available in the context menu of Method Invocation view, but the button/action is not available in the view tool bar menu.
Please see Execution Flow view for an example of the menu tool bar button.

bug.short_desc: Transcient validation error after copying WSDL and XSD file

long_desc.thetext:
In skeleton and client scenario, after WSDL files are copied, some WSDL and XSD files are showing validation error (XSD not resolved) but the imported files are actually there. This validation error would go away when a manual validation is done.
We suspect the problem is there because when the WSDL and XSD files are copied, it's imports are not copied yet but the WSDL validator had already been started on that file.
The solution would be to enclose the CopyWSDLCommand in a workspace modify operation.
Assigned and targetted to 1.5.3.
Patch provided in bug 165723.
Released to HEAD and R1_5_maintenance.
Verified on WTP 1.5.3 20070125 driver. Closing.

bug.short_desc: Access to external node data while doing Layout Algorithm

long_desc.thetext:
Is there a way to access the model data associated to any InternalNode during a Layout computation? I do think that there is legitimate reason to allow this, since layout algorithms more often than not require context information to do their work.
Ian Bull suggests: "We have the notion of LayoutConstraints. If you are building a new layout alogirthm, or what to get information about your external node, we could offer something like a ConstraintContentProvider. If this was set on the viewer, whenever you need information about layout constraints you could call node.getLayoutEntity().populateLayoutConstraint(...) with your custom layout constraint. If you had a LayoutConstraintProvider, then this could forward the event there. You would get a call like
populateLayoutConstraint( MyLayoutConstraint c, Object e ) where e would be your node, and c would be your custom constraint. you could then do something like c.setMyInformation ( ((MyNode)e).attributeIWant);"
This approach is a clean solution, that gives the flexibility to have view separated by model, and it follows in the JFace viewer structure.

I have added a snippet to tests that shows how to use the layout constraint on the spring layout algorithm. This example sets a higher weight on a spring if it is connected to the root.
In doing this I found a few small bugs (layout constraints where not working for connections) that I fixed.

Targeting to future since not containable in 4.4.

As discussed on this week's Test Project call (January 22, 2007), the Test Project will focus on existing P1 - P2/Blocker - Major and P1/Normal and test creation/automation defects (omitting defects dependant on outstanding features) in TPTP 4.4. long_desc.thetext:
./all/org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.doc.isv/tasks/texportsdb.htm 58 Misspelled word: api ./all/org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.doc.isv/tasks/timportsdb.htm 24 Misspelled word: apis ./all/org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.doc.isv/tasks/timportsdb.htm 68 Misspelled word: apis ./all/org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.doc.isv/tasks/timportsdb.htm 73 Misspelled word: apis ./all/org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.doc.isv/tasks/tconfiguremanifestfile.html 108 Misspelled word: combobox ./all/org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.doc.user/samples/slog_analyzer.html 63 Misspelled word: unselect
- "api" and "api" are wrong because "API" is an acronym. These words should be capitalized. - "combobox" should be the name of the box instead. "combobox" isn't a real word (it's a short form of "combination box"). - "unselect" isn't really a word. Use "clear" instead.
This is not a stop ship issue for 4.3 - deferring to 4.4.
Targetting to complete in iteration 3 and raising priority to indicate it is planned for 4.4.
I'll attach files with other spelling errors in Monitoring Tools plugins that were found during TPTP 4.3.1 testing.

bug.short_desc: Can't mark multiple local and web tasks completed

long_desc.thetext: It is possible to mark individual query hits from web query completed, but this action is disable when there is more then one hit selected. It is quite critical, since we decided for now to manage completed status locally.
Since the web connector is currently the only driver for this assigning to you. If you aren't able to do it I might be able to get to it but not until week after next, just let me know.
I wonder why it is specific to the web connector? Anyways, any hints where to look at this would be really helpful.

Right--it's not specific to the web connector, it would also be useful for normal tasks. But in terms of having it for 1.0 the web connector seems like the only driver since I can not recall this being requested.
The problem is that MarkTaskComplete only enables itself for a single task to keep the logic simpler. Note that there is already some messy and fragile logic there having to deal with WebTask's not being properly encapsulated.

Created an attachment (id=54944) Refectored mark complete and mark read actions
This patch introduce new methods on ITaskElement: canComplete() and canRead(). This way all fragile logic is removed and concrete artifacts can say if they can be completed and read.
I also moved saving of the TaskList into background job. As a result, all group actions, including mark and schedule don't block the UI thread anymore, and because saving is quite slow (2..3 secs on my task list), many sequential requests are skipped now and I observe great improvement in UI responsivness.
Created an attachment (id=54945) mylar/context/zip
Did this get resolved already by your other patch?

(In reply to comment #6) > Did this get resolved already by your other patch?
This was the only patch about this.
Anyways, you seriously need to think about fixing class hierarchy starting from the ITaskListElement

Ooops, got confused between patches, ignore comment#6. canRead() and canRename() does not belong on ITaskListElement for the reasons I mentioned. Yes, we need to improve that hierarchy, but that's for the 2.0 stream.

(In reply to comment #8) > canRead() and canRename() does not belong on ITaskListElement for > the reasons I mentioned.
I disagree. It should be possible to mark entire folder/category as read or complete. That is particularly useful for web queries.

That's not an operation on the container element, which should not store a "read" state. It's a UI-specific thing where the user's intention on marking a container complete clearly indicates all children of it should be marked complete. Not a model thing.

(In reply to comment #10) > That's not an operation on the container element, which should not store a > "read" state. It's a UI-specific thing where the user's intention on marking a > container complete clearly indicates all children of it should be marked > complete. Not a model thing.
Arguably. It is a meta model that is mostly used by ui at the moment. So, there should be some way to query element capacities and instanceof is not the best thing for that. You said yourself that code is fragile...

Mik, are you going to address this issue any time soon? Should be easy for you, because you already implemented "mark as read" for multiple tasks. Please consider it for 2.0
Since you have your own view on how this should be implemented, I am not planning to provide patches for this.
PS: I noticed that currently it is not possible to mark even single query hit as completed if it does not have task. So, it need to be marked as red first.
I have no additional time to investigate this for 2.0.

Created an attachment (id=72273) patch for complete/incomplete actions for multiple local tasks
Here is patch that enables complete/incomplete actions for multiple local tasks. Please review and apply if possible for 2.0. It is extremely useful when working with web queries.
Created an attachment (id=72274) mylyn/context/zip

Patch applied. However, I had to remove enablement problems, ensure that the dialog did not show up when a single task was selected (a UI guideline) and create a superclass for the copy/pasted code. Note that I may not be able to apply patches of this sort for 2.0, although I'm glad that this got in.
One more thing I had to fix was the "null" showing for local task keys.

Thanks Mik.
BTW, one thing might be useful there is to show an alert that there is no local tasks found, just to reduce confusion if mark operation didn't do anything.

attachment.desc: Refectored mark complete and mark read actions
patch for complete/incomplete actions for multiple local tasks

I made the drop down read only. Labels and icons not yet supported but feel free to file a bug for that.

bug.short_desc: [Help] doc.zip files in plug-in require doc.zip files in fragments

long_desc.thetext:
The Eclipse product documentation states that when resolving file names in unpackaged plug-ins that contain a doc.zip archive, the doc.zip is checked first for the file. A plug-in and its fragments are supposed to be equivalent to one logical plug-in but this does not appear to be the case. The documentation for file lookup says: -------------- The help plug-in will look for this file as follows: look in doc.zip for the file /html/ref/ref1.html look for the file ref1.html in the /html/ref sub-directory structure underneath the plug-in directory.
http://help.eclipse.org/help31/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/help_plugin_files.htm -------------- However, when the default locale file exists in a plug-in doc.zip and the translation exists in an NL fragment that is not in a doc.zip (but has the same Eclipse path) the translated file will not be resolved.
This constraint is not defined anywhere in the Eclipse documentation, nor does it seem to be the desired behaviour. Perhaps it is an Eclipse platform or at least documentation bug?
Workaround: The only work around I have tried to come up with is to ensure that all fragment files under the 'nl/<locale>' are packaged exactly the same as their corresponding plug-in.
Aside: This also causes problems if a plug-in is unpacked (a plug-in directory) and fragments for that plug-in are JAR files. JAR files can not contain doc.zip archives, so the translated material is not found. Having an unpackaged primary plug-in is required in some environments so that the service provider can launch an IEHS with the -plugin_customization flag in the start string. This can lead to problems that would not be apparent following documentation.
Created an attachment (id=54450) sample plugin

Actually this is documented in the link you provided. Under the "National language and translated documentation" section it says "If you are using a doc.zip file, you should produce a doc.zip file for each locale and place it inside the correct locale directory."
I recommend (to everyone) switching from using doc.zip files to jarred plug-ins, where you don't have to worry about this any longer. The doc.zip was invented specifically for help before you could jar plug-ins, and as you can see has some restrictions.
Resolving as won't fix.

bug.short_desc: [Quick Access] Simplify new Ctrl-E popup

long_desc.thetext:
It is really great to see that you are addressing long standing issue about quick and natural navigation between views, editors and perspectives. So, I was really pleased so see new Ctrl-E popup in Eclipse 3.3M3.
However I believe there is a big space for improvement here. First of all it would make sense to hide all the items that are shown now and only present currently open views, editors and perspectives. Then, similarly to other poput dialogs (Ctrl-O, Ctrl-T in JDT) you can unfilter those on second Ctrl-E hit.
Also, it would be interesting to be able to use this popup instead of Ctrl-F5/F6/F7, to make navigation even more easy. Currently I remapped Ctrl-F5 on Ctrl-Tab and that work really great for jumping between editors (Ctrl-Tab, Tab, Tab...)
Another thing worth to mention that when all views are shown it does make sense to group then the same vay as Open View dialod does.

Thanks for your input.
I agree that this needs lots of polish and tweaking. This is why we put something in without actively promoting it yet. ;)

(In reply to comment #2) > I agree that this needs lots of polish and tweaking. This is why we put > something in without actively promoting it yet. ;)
Heh. You sort of broke good old Ctrl-E popup and don't really offer a good replacement for Ctrl-Tab. :-(

Not sure what you mean - Ctrl-F6 is next editor, if you bind it to Ctrl-Tab, you can still tab through your editors.
Ctrl-F5 is bound to "Step into Selection" by default. (I didn't even know you could do that...)

(In reply to comment #4) > Not sure what you mean - Ctrl-F6 is next editor, if you bind it to Ctrl-Tab, > you can still tab through your editors.
Right. But I think it would bereally handy to include views into the same loop. I never been able to understand why you had to have 3 separate shortcuts for switching between editors, views and perspectives? Think about it. There are so many use cases when developer jump between editors and views.
-- persistence/xml mappings: edit code, jump into special view to edit persistence properties (i.e. when using Dali). -- digging troug junit tests. junit view allows to jump into the editor, but it is not easy to get back to junit view if developer need to move to next failure -- same for debug view, same for package explorer view -- and so on and so worth.
> Ctrl-F5 is bound to "Step into Selection" by default. (I didn't even know you > could do that...)
Sorry, I meant Ctrl-F6/F7/F8. Those shortcuts are so not natural.

bug.short_desc: Related bugs feature

long_desc.thetext:
This is just an crazy idea I had, and I'm posting just to register it hopping someone can investigate some day.
It would be interesting to have a feature where the bug editor can show a "related bugs" list.
This list can be just a hint, lazily populated using the set of accessed tasks, by computing:
1 - Bugs it refers to by recognizing hyperlinks (bug#<number>). 2 - Bugs that refers to it (the same as (1), but "on demand" as the bugs are accessed and the links are discovered). This is interesting because usually you refer to other bugs via hyperlinking, but never knows what others refers to you. 3 - Inter-repository bug linking by recognizing other repository's URL.
Migrating local task storage to lucene would help a lot...

Yes, this is really similar to what we used to have waaaay back with 0.2 and active search of bugs. So we actually have all that background search infrastructure, but for 1.0 had to put the focus on repository integration and remove it from the active search stuff. I'll mark helpwanted for now. The old background task repository search code is in the sandbox.

bug.short_desc: Tasklist is not thread-safe

long_desc.thetext: While working on bug#164661 I figured out that the task list implementation is not thread-safe. This prevents doing concurrent changes by background jobs.
*** Bug 165746 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Could you create a failing test or steps to reproduce failure? We addressed some of the thread safety problems way back, but not all.

This is the worst type of bug to reproduce :)
I just started many AddExistingTaskJobs concurrently, and TaskList.addTask(...) (or some called method, I don't remember) threw a ConcurrentModificationException.
Sorry, but I hadn't time yesterday to investigate better, but I assume that either:
- TaskList.addTask(...) (or TaskList) does not handle concurrent operations. - Some other method is accessing/iterating some internal collection of tasklist while the addTask operation is occurring.
Regarding the last one, if I'm not wrong, there are many methods, not only on tasklist that return internal collections. This is not a good practice because can lead to unexpected ConcurrentModificationExceptions and you are exposing a internal structure.
Yes, I forgot to open a bug for this :), but on this cases, the better is to never return the internal collection, but always wrap it (or its subset, if creating a new one) with a Collection.unmodifiedList/Set/Collection.
In the RC phase I will take a better look at current implementation and make some suggestions regarding concurrent techniques.

Yes, we'll iterate on that class exactly as you suggest in the RC phase. In particular to get rid of exposing internals. The Task List's is actually continually getting modified in an asynchronous way because we allow synchronization jobs that update tasks in parallel. But we have never had a scenario where multiple addTask(..)s happen in parallel so that's a good lead.

BTW, I believe Collection.unmodifiedList/Set/Collection is still iterating trough the original collection. So, you better to iterate trough the copy and I recall submitting a patch for this at some point. Heh, maybe it didn't fix all the places...

(In reply to comment #5) > BTW, I believe Collection.unmodifiedList/Set/Collection is still iterating > trough the original collection.
Yes, you are absolutely right. The unmodified(...) stuff is a recommended practice to avoid exposing the internal collection structure.
About the iteration, it is better to ensure that the clients of method make it through a new collection created from the return by the method.
Should be handling most cases now. For future improvements in this regard will need failing scenarios.

bug.short_desc: No parameter show in Oracle dataset after inputing a select sentence including '<?'[0703]

long_desc.thetext: Description: No parameter show in Oracle dataset after inputing a select sentence including '<?'[0703] Build number: 2.2.0.v20061123-0710 Steps to reproduce: 1, New a Oracle datasource and dataset 2, Input a select sentence such as select * from table1 where table1.id < ? 3, Turn to the Parameters in dataset Expected result: A auto created parameter without default value shows in the Parameter Actual result: No parameter created automatically. Error log: N/A

Cancel this bug since oracle's jdbc driver doesn't return any ParameterMetaData by calling its getParameterMetadata() method. Insteadly, it throws "Unsupported feature" SQLExcetpion. So we cannot display any automatically generated parameter metadata for Oracle.
verified and closed

bug.short_desc: [inline] Inline local in constructor with compile error does remove code

long_desc.thetext:
The problem is that "s" in "this(s)" does not have a binding, see bug 166963.
But even without the "this(s);", the refactoring dialog currently says "Inline 0 occurrences of local variable 's'?", which amounts to removing the declaration.
We could show a warning in cases where 0 occurrences have been found, e.g. "The local variable 's' is not referenced anywhere. Do you want to remove the declaration?".
I'm not sure what the quick assist should do if there are no references, since it has no way to warn the user. Martin?
Fix for bug 166963 got scheduled for 3.3M7

Verified that the fix for bug 166963 fixes comment 0.
Improved message in the Inline Local Variable dialog to tell that the variable declaration will simply be removed when no references are found.

bug.short_desc: UI looses context after switching tab

long_desc.thetext:
How to reproduce:
1) insert chart and redefine some JS method. The chart was selected in Layout tab and you see list of JS methods to be redefined. 2) switch to preview tab 3) switch to script tab - no object is selected and there is only message "This element has no methods.". When I switch to layout tab, the chart is still selected and then switching to script tab will show chart JS methods.
Expected behaviour: 1) select chart in layout 2) switch to script tab, chart JS methods are there 3) switch to preview tab 4) switch to script tab, chart JS methods are there

This is very annoying bug, which is very common to all UI elements in BIRT. For example I open data sets in Navigator, click to preview tab, click back and data sets are closed again. Ok, it is just one additional (useless click) to open data sets in Navigator. But outline contains very deep tree and it suffers from the same bug. For example I open Body > Table > Detail > Row > Cell > Label and edit it. Then I look for preview and when I return to do additional changes, body tree node is closed and I have to locate Label again by clicking on Body > Table > Detail > Row > Cell. It is very frustrating, please fix it as soon as possible. Thanks
*** Bug 173058 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Well we have got conflicting requirements for this feature. Some one have told that when in preview page, we shall show blank page in property page and maybe clear other view. This means the current selection is blank. But this bug ask up to keep the current selection. Also if we try to remember the selection for every page is also complicated. Assume if user select a table in layout and later switch to script page, we have to keep the table as current selection. So the script page itself doesn't have it's own selection.

+1 for keeping the property editor and pallete view when user switch to preview. When user switch back from preview, we shall keep the selection.
Is there solution to acheive this behavior?

The first issue in main description is fixed and the property editor now is kept when switch between different tabs.
Need investigate on resolution for comment 1.
I think we need more time to investigate this.
Fixed it.

The current state of affairs does not allow to copy the text, although it allows text *selection* on this page.

bug.short_desc: [Contributions] viewActions for editors

long_desc.thetext: It would be nice to have editorActions extension points to contribute actions to the editor toolbar and editor pulldown menu. For now there is no toolbar and pulldown for the editor.

As part of bug 154130 the editorActions and viewActions are being refactored into one extension point. View actions are created using menu:my.view.id. What were editorActions are created using menu:org.eclipse.ui.main.menu since that's where they go, and editorActions was really only about visibility.
That means that theoretically, menu:my.editor.id could be used to create editor part menus. The same applies for toolbar:my.editor.id.
This won't be supported in 3.3 because not only do you need to define editor actions, but you need the presentation to support them, and that's huge API work as well as presentation work.
But at least the new menu API doesn't prevent it going forward.
PW

bug.short_desc: customBuildCallbacks - design error

long_desc.thetext:
You have 2 plugins, both shall use the same customBuildCallbacks.xml, so you write in both plugins build.properties: customBuildCallbacks=../mydefaultcallbacks/customBuildCallbacks.xml
Then you have a 3th plugin, that shall use different callbacks, so in this plugins build.properties you write: customBuildCallbacks=./customBuildCallbacks.xml
And then you have a feature, that shall use callbacks as well, but whatever you write in this features build.properties, you will end up with this message:
[available] DEPRECATED - <available> used to override an existing property. [available] Build file should not reuse the same property name for different values.

I'm surprised we haven't seen this earlier. It appears that the plugin's build.xml is inheriting the customBuildCallbacks property from the feature.
Either we figure out how to not have that property inherited, or we need to name them uniquely. The name would likely need to be based on the name of the feature/plugin since nested features will inherit their parent's property (so simply naming them customFeatureCallbacks and customPluginCallbacks would not be enough).
This appears to be a warning and the callbacks are still being called.

> ... since nested features will inherit their parent's property (so > simply naming them customFeatureCallbacks and customPluginCallbacks > would not be enough)
Hmm - that would have been my solution proposal, but it looks like you are right.
Even more, one of my collegues says, that even plugins can consist of just a list of plugins. (This shall be usefull to create a bundled interface for actually a bunch of plugins.) If so, the inheritance vs. redefinition problem also exists for plugin-of-plugin situations.

Created an attachment (id=64788) Test case showing the problem
Here is a test case showing the problem. To reproduce, generate the scripts on the feature (f or f2) and then run the script on "build.jars" target on the feature.
Even though the warning is ugly / scary, the attach test case shows that the proper behavior is being executed (see the hello messages printed into the console). Therefore I don't think we should try to fix that for 3.3. Ever? this is another question?

bug.short_desc: Enhance combo box cell editor to support typing a prefix filter

long_desc.thetext: The combobox-based cell editor (ExtendedComboBoxCellEditor) is cumbersome to use when the list is long. E.g. when entering the eType of an attribute in the Ecore editor, it takes a lot of mousing to find EString. A great enhancement is to support typing a prefix filter, to make the list shorter and possibly only 1 element long. E.g. typing 'e', 's', 't' is enough to select EString and a lot faster. I've implemented this using a technique described in the SWT newsgroup, in a drop-in replacement for ExtendedComboBoxCellEditor. The source is (will be) attached to a comment.

Created an attachment (id=54469) A replacement with support for typing a prefix filter.
The code listens to keys, collects the prefix and filters the list, using a technique described in the SWT newsgroup.

[contrib email="hal@idi.ntnu.no"/]
This is a very helpful contribution. I got so used to having this convenience it quickly became annoying not to have it. I've committed the changes to HEAD.

attachment.desc: A replacement with support for typing a prefix filter.

bug.short_desc: [jres] Eclipse runtime jre is always added to the Installed JRE even same JRE is defined by the extension org.eclipse.jdt.launching.vmInstalls

long_desc.thetext:
Even if installed JRE is defined by extension org.eclipse.jdt.launching.vmInstalls, eclipse runtime jre (jre which eclipse is running) is added to the Installed JRE. This happens even the location of JRE are same.
I think the eclipse runtime jre should be added to the Installed JRE only if there are no other installed JRE defined, or only if there are no other installed jre with same location.
Not planned for 3.3

bug.short_desc: Incorrect relevance of content assist proposals

long_desc.thetext: The content assist proposals are ordered by relevance. The relevance ranking mechnism seems to be slightly incorrect. It does not display the most relevant local variable first, if the case is incorrect. Please see the attached screenshots.

Created an attachment (id=54471) wrong relevance if incorrect case given
This screenshot shows the best match as second proposal, because a lower-case t is given instead of a capital T.
Created an attachment (id=54472) Correct proposal with correct case.

Created an attachment (id=54473) correct proposal for a shorter input
If no t is given the correct proposal is shown. If one now adds a lower-case t, the correct proposal stays on top.
I guess this is JDT Core relevance.

With test case of comment 1
The first type has the following relevance criterion. - 'datat' is a prefix of the type name 'DataTransfertContextBase' if case is ignored - the type doesn't need to be qualified (probably already imported)
Each other types have the following relevance criterion - 'datat' is a prefix of the type name if case is ignored - the type needs to be qualified (not imported)
The local variable reference has the following relevance criterion - 'datat' is a prefix of the variable 'dataTransertService'name if case is ignored - the name doesn't need to qualified (it's a local variable)
As you can see the first type and the local variable have currently the same relevance.
Why do you think that the local variable should be more relevant ? - because it's a local variable ? - because the first character is strictly equals to the prefix first character even if the other part of the name is equals by ignoring case ? - another reason ?
Your test case show another problem. DataTransertService type is probably already imported but it is shown as less relevant.

David, thank you for your response.
Yes, I think the local variable should be proposed first because it's local and I think more likely to be used. And yes, only one letter got the wrong case whereas for 'DataTransfertContextBase' two letters got wrong case.
To say it more general: If the input starts with a capital letter, I most likely want to use a class or interface name or a final static variable (something that normally starts with a capital letter). If the input starts with a lower case letter I most likely mean a local or instance variable (or something that starts with a lower case letter). Maybe it would be best to check the first character with strong equality and the remainder with ignoring case.
The DataTransferService, DataTransferServiceTest, DataTransferContextBase and DataTransferContextBaseTest are all defined in the same package (but in different source trees).

attachment.desc: wrong relevance if incorrect case given
correct proposal for a shorter input

bug.short_desc: CDT C syntax parser support for C extensions in ISO/IEC DTR 18037

long_desc.thetext:
It should be nice if CDT has a support for some C syntax extensions.
It is quite common to have to use some extensions in C syntax when developing for embedded environments. One of the extensions I should currently suggest is the ones described in ISO/IEC DTR 18037 document at http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/www/docs/n1021.pdf. The extensions are described in Chapter 3.
