bug.short_desc: No content assist and F3 or link on classes in java editor with EAR library

long_desc.thetext:
The problem occurs with Eclipse 3.2.1 and WTP 1.5.2 (and 1.5.1, by the way). The contents of my workspace is: one EAR project, some utility java projects (with source) and some utility java projects as binary projects. Binary projects are simple java projects, that have no sources, no source folder and no output folder, but instead a library with compiled contents; in the file .classpath of the binary project is an entry like <classpathentry path="MyProject.jar" exported="true" kind="lib" />. In the ear project some projects are checked in the J2EE-Module Dependencies, and these modules are also checked in the J2EE-Module Dependencies of the utility java projects (with source). When the same utility java project (with source) uses the binary projects, the problem occurs. The problem disappears when I uncheck the J2EE-Module Dependencies, when I delete the binary project from the classpath or when I convert the binary project to a source project.
To give you a better understanding, here an example (Bin means binary project, Src means source project, EAR is an Enterprise Project):
MyEAR is my Enterprise Project and contains J2EE-Module Dependencies to three source projects Src1, Src2, Src3. In Src1 I have an J2EE-Module Dependency to Src2 and in the classpath project Bin1 is used. In Src2 I have an J2EE-Module Dependency to Src3 and in the classpath projects Bin1, Bin2, Bin3, Bin4 are used. In Src3 there are only classpath entries to projects Bin3 and Bin4.
The problem itself shows like this: there is no F3 (Strg+Click) support for some classes in the utility java project (named Src1). The hyperlink underline does not appear and the F3 click doesn't do anything. In my example I can not go to BigDecimal or String in the source-code, but it works for my own classes and (surprisingly) in the import section of a class.
Any help appreciated,
Thanks
Achim
Charles, please investigate these defects

(In reply to comment #1) > Charles, please investigate these defects
Hi Charles,
did you find any solution to my problem ?
I appreciate any help !!!
Achim
Re-assigning owner for now....

bug.short_desc: Modeling Project "sub-component" newsgroups not standard [was: Modeling Project "component" newsgroups not standard]

long_desc.thetext:
Newsgroup creation has typically been limited to one newsgroup per Eclipse.org project. We recently noticed that the modeling.mdt and modeling.gmt projects have several newsgroups, some even nested, when only eclipse.modeling.mdt and eclipse.modeling.gmt should exist.
Project leads, please advise your respective communities that the component newsgroups below will be deleted next week:
eclipse.modeling.gmt.amw eclipse.modeling.gmt.modisco eclipse.modeling.mdt.eodm eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.ocl eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.uml eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.tools eclipse.modeling.mdt.xsd

Apologies... I meant "beyond the component level". That only affects these groups:
eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.ocl eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.uml eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.tools
I assume these groups match a component, and are okay: eclipse.modeling.gmt.amw eclipse.modeling.gmt.modisco eclipse.modeling.mdt.eodm eclipse.modeling.mdt.xsd

Many thanks Denis,
... so I consider that for the GMT components MoDisco and AMW there is no concern and that at this "component" level there will be no problem in creating newsgroups.
Jean Bezivin
(In reply to comment #1) > Apologies... I meant "beyond the component level". That only affects these > groups: > eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.ocl > eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.uml > eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.tools > I assume these groups match a component, and are okay: > eclipse.modeling.gmt.amw > eclipse.modeling.gmt.modisco > eclipse.modeling.mdt.eodm > eclipse.modeling.mdt.xsd

> ... so I consider that for the GMT > components MoDisco and AMW there is no concern > and that at this "component" level there > will be no problem in creating newsgroups.
The MoDisco and AMW groups are fine. Our unwritten policy is to create only one newsgroup per project, and although we don't encourage component groups, we do tolerate them when the project group gets too much traffic (such as eclipse.platform, which was split into eclipse.platform.rcp and eclipse.platform.swt).

Whoah, where does this policy exist? Why weren't we informed about this before the newsgroups were created in the first place? How many more times are we going to move the newgroups around?
Note that since the UML2 OCL, UML2 UML, and UML2 Tools are separately downloadable subcomponents of MDT, with potentially different user communities, it seems reasonable that they have separate newsgroups. The primary motivation here was to separate issues with tools based on UML2 from the actual metamodel standards (OCL and UML).

(In reply to comment #4) > Whoah, where does this policy exist?
The policy is "is anyone else doing this?" and if not, the other policy is "what if all the project started doing this". Looking at all the existing groups, there is no precedent for what UML2 is doing with its newsgroups.
> Why weren't we informed about this before > the newsgroups were created in the first place?
Because we didn't notice it until Someone brought it to our attention.
> How many more times are we > going to move the newgroups around?
I'm not sure what this means.
> Note that since the UML2 OCL, UML2 UML, and UML2 Tools are separately > downloadable subcomponents of MDT, with potentially different user communities,
But they're still UML2, which itself isn't a project, but a component of MDT, right? The question is, do you really *need* three groups for UML? Imagine if each project started spawning each "component of a component" into its own newsgroup.
We've scheduled the deletion of eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.ocl, eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.uml and eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.tools for Nov. 30, in favor of a single eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2 group.
Perhaps if the structure in MDT were not so slavish to the OMG's structure of UML specifications, it would be better? IOW, move UML2 Tools, and OCL up to "first class components" within MDT.

I'm sorry, but I have an issue with scheduling the deletion (you don't really mean deletion do you - what about the thread history?) of these newsgroups until this discussion is closed.
I though it was common practice to spawn a separate newsgroup in situations where the threads in one group are not of interest to the same user group. In this case, we know that the audiences of OCL, UML, and Tools (under the umbrella of UML2 - not UML) are often different.
I'm by no means advocating the creation of separate groups for every subcomponent... but in cases where it has been deemed necessary, it seems quite inflexible of the foundation not to allow it.

(In reply to comment #7) > I'm sorry, but I have an issue with scheduling the deletion (you don't really > mean deletion do you - what about the thread history?) of these newsgroups > until this discussion is closed.
Well, I guess we have 1.5 days to close this discussion. At any rate, the HTML archives of these groups will remain publicly accessible, but the newsgroups will be deleted.
> but in cases where it has been deemed necessary
Necessary? By whom? According to webster, a necessity is: The quality or state of being necessary, unavoidable, or absolutely requisite; inevitableness; indispensableness. [1913 Webster]
I think the UML groups absolutely don't fall under the "necessary" definition. However, to our users, the confusion of having x UML groups is real. Right now, we have, by design, a very low number of newsgroups on our server -- and from the news user's perspective, I think that's a good thing. Case in point: the eclipse.platform newsgroup happily carries on discussion pertaining to just about every subject without the need to segregate their community.
Please work with your community to move discussion to eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.

I don't understand why there needs to be any correspondence between Eclipse Projects/Components and newsgroups. A newsgroup is a medium in which a community can discuss common concerns and ideas. In Eclipse, those discussions often involve particular projects, but sometimes they do not (viz. eclipse.eclipsecon, eclipse.employment). In any case, there are more dimensions in which discussion takes place than just the project structure.
The UML, OCL, and Tools newsgroups all have different target audiences: UML is used primarily by developers of UML-based applications, OCL by developers of EMF-based applications (at least, if you include the history of OCL in the EMFT newsgroup), and Tools is used primarily by users of the UML-based application that is the Tools component. I think that this distinction rather helps users, who can better focus the discussion on their concerns and keep matters that are of less interest out of their newsreaders by not subscribing.
Would the Foundation require that, when "components" (small c, which is in itself an ambiguous term) have different user communities, they must be instituted as separate Components (as Rich suggests, comment #6) or even Projects? In this case, the Foundation would then be required to provide separate newsgroups? Are there criteria that constrain the subdivision of Projects into Components? Surely, the goal isn't to limit the number of newsgroups.

Changing newsgroups in the first place already strikes me as a little bit jerking the users of the existings newsgroups around. That's why I've not migrated the EMF newsgroup, i.e., I don't want to lose the valuable history it contains; yes, I know they are archived, but folks have enough trouble finding information without having a list of archives to search (nor bouncing newsgroups to chase down). In this case too, I can certainly imagine that folks using OCL might not care a hoot about UML2; they might be using OCL purely with Ecore. So the new newsgroups definitely target different audiences.
Changing the newsgroups a second time based on unpublished "guidelines" strikes me as unreasonable and to take the further step of simply decreeing that they will disappear by a certain date without a discusion about the right course of action is not the way I expect the Eclipse organization to function. One would get the impression that having additional newsgroups is somehow a major inconvenience (cost?) to the foundation itself, which I believe is not the case. If it serves the Eclipse user community well, then it serves the foundation's purpose perfectly. I don't think the flood gates of all those with newsgroup envy will be unleashed thereby creating an unmanageable demand that would exhuast our newsgroup supply...
In this case we seem to be splitting hairs because of the package naming of the components. If OCL remains as org.eclipse.emf.ocl, or becomes org.eclipse.ocl, then it can have its own newsgroup in MDT, but if it is renamed to org.eclipse.uml.ocl then it cannot? So simply the name is sufficient to warrant a new newsgroup or not? I'm not sure that reasoning make sense nor that it serves the user community well. (I think this would be Rich's point.)
Certainly the first step here would be to write the unwritten policies before acting on them, but the approach instead seems to be, it's just going to be deleted and if you don't like it that's just too bad because we can delete it if we want and you can't stop us no matter much you might disagree with our unwritten policy or even with our policy of having enforced unwritten policies.
I know I'm over stating things, but I'm telling you the feeling it generates. So I'm sorry that I'm getting snarky about this, but I'm kind of taken aback at the dictatorial nature of this discussion (in it can even be called that). Kenn's and Christian's opinions and their user community seem to carry far less weight relative to an apparently far more important overriding unwritten policiy. That doesn't seem right for a public foundation.
How about we look at some simple facts, such as the volume of traffic on the OCL newsgroup so far relative to the volume of traffic on some other newsgroups, even top level ones for that matter. For example, the OCL newsgroup generates more traffic (45 since 6/ll) than the DTP newsgroup (21). So how can we argue to eliminate the OCL newsgroup but keep the DTP one? (I'm really not suggesting we should delete DTP's newsgroup!) Sure the WTP newsgroup attracts 3 times that volume, but only three times, and it's apparently the most popular project right now.
In the end I think the policiy should be that if the community is well served by having a newsgroup, it should have one. Kenn and Christian are the best folks to speak to how to serve their community best so I don't think we should arbitrarily over rule them by decree based on unwritten policies. Please reconsider...

The discussion around newsgroup naming has been brought up several times [1]. Actually, it was always said that we align the newsgroups with the projects and not topics. I'm also not sure if we really have newsgroups for components. For example, Draw2D, JFace, Team CVS all don't have separate newsgroups. I don't know if that makes sense, though. The naming policy [2] doesn't define those.
[1] bug 111923, bug 19399, bug 21727, bug 73282, etc. [2] http://www.eclipse.org/projects/dev_process/project-naming-policy.php

There's an RCP newsgroup and I think that's more of a topic than a component, right? ;-) Same goes for the newcomer newsgroup, unless there is a newcomer component I haven't spotted yet. ;-)
I think it's the one additional level of nesting in this case that's bothering people more than anything else, so if org.eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2 were removed (I don't think there's any traffic there and I don't think that newsgroup is useful) and the things under it were moved up one level, perhaps folks would stop being bothered?

Policies. Geez, why the sudden need for bureaucracy?
a) The naming policy [1] clearly implies the 1:1 project:newsgroup in the first sentence: "The project newsgroup name will be eclipse.[toplevel].[shortname]"
b) The project provisioning request [2] that you filled out recently also clearly implies that it's a 1:1 project:newsgroup ratio. There is no room on that form to define multiple newsgroups, but there is space to define multiple mailing lists. Do we need to explicitly state that "there is no field for additional newsgroups because we don't allow multiple newsgroups"?
To me, it seems that by allowing the UML2 "component" of the MDT project to have it's own newsgroup, we're already being more flexible to your project's needs than the written policy and provisioning forms allow.
[1] http://www.eclipse.org/projects/dev_process/project-naming-policy.php [2] http://www.eclipse.org/projects/project_provisioning_request.php
Both those documents also imply the 1:1 project:website ratio too. 1:1 project:downloads area... 1:1 project:cvs repository. I see a pattern of 1:1's here that, from my side of the fence, prevents our infrastructure from becoming insanely difficult to manage. Less insanity == less cost to the Foundation, faster response time to community requests, faster, stable infrastructure.
Also, I think you need to consider (and balance) the needs of a small community [OCL] vs. the needs of the Eclipse community as a whole, who all share the same resouces within the same namespace. You've all been around for years, so the fact that UML2 has three groups may make perfect sense to you. But what about the vast majority of people who don't spend their days here? More groups == more complexity, more options and more channels, more confusion. http://www.joelonsoftware.com/items/2006/11/21.html is a good read about how often, less is more.
Eclipse.newcomer was created for that Very Large Audience that looks at our (already large) news server, complex website and our news pages, and say "what a mess... Where do I ask this question about topic xyz??). When the UML2 group gets to the point where there's way too much traffic for it to be coherent, then there will be a need for separate groups and we'll definitely accomodate that.
The RCP group was created before the Foundation, so it's off-bounds.
I have clearly identified why these groups must go, and I have a) policy and b) lack of precedence to explain why, whereas there doesn't seem to be a real need for 3 UML2 groups. Policies aside, let's be realistic. If there's really a good reason for these groups to exist, then I suggest the Modeling PMC contact the EMO directly -- there's not much more I can do.

Denis,
You bemoan bureaucracy but then wield it like a sword to achieve your goal of "these newsgroups must go". I don't like bureaucracy either and to be really blunt, I care about the rules to the extent that they achieve useful results; when they stop achieving useful results then they have stopped serving their purpose well and should be questioned. You also talk about reducing the complexity of maintaining infrastructure but don't seem to be the least bit bothered that the user community and the folks serving them have to deal with-now-you-seem-them-now-you-don't newsgroups; Kenn and Christian are the folks who answer these newsgroups and their opinions shouldn't be ignored because 1:1 rules seem to make their opinions irrelevant.
Rich and I are the PMC leads and since the EMO is also on the CC list I believe we are directly contacting the EMO about this issue. I am asking both the EMO and you to not take steps that upset to folks serving the community. I don't believe it's your place to decide to delete a newsgroup according to the arbitrary schedule of your choosing; it's quite a different issue not to create one until all is settled, but having created one, it's really not your place to simply deleted it. After all, the world will not end if the newsgroups continue to exist until we close this discussion in a way that everyone can live with into the future.
So I fully expect no action will be taken until the discussions resolve. I'd like to hear from the EMO why it's strictly necessary to delete a newsgroup that gets more traffic than even some of the top level newsgroups...

Just the usual complaint, from the viewpoint of (re)users of just small parts of UML:
Wed still like to be able to focus in OCL, without having to watch for the whole UML2 discourse.
Therefore, we would like OCL to retain an independent news channel.

Interesting discussion. It looks like we are experiencing the usual Eclipse-related tension between two interests (the projects and the membership). I see three solutions to this problem: 1. no change - members are confused about project/newsgroup structure and this makes the EMO unhappy 2. reduce the number of newsgroups to match the number of projects - newsgroups are cluttered and this makes Modeling users and leaders and the EMO unhappy 3. increase the number of projects to match the number of newsgroups - everyone is happy Before I go into detail about #3, let me try to summarize what I've read so far:
* eclipse.modeling.gmt.* and eclipse.modeling.mdt.* are the only places in the newsgroup hierarchy that exceed [toplevel].[subproject] or [toplevel].[subtopic] naming [comment #0] * The EMO prefers one newsgroup per project but when a newsgroup gets significant traffic on a particular topic, we open a newsgroup for that topic [comment #3] * Ed, Kenn, and Christian believe that when multiple newsgroup are deemed necessary, "it seems quite inflexible of the foundation not to allow [them]" [comment #7] * The EMO has taken the position that "by design, a very low number of newsgroups on our server -- and from the news user's perspective, I think that's a good thing" because "more groups = more complexity, more options and more channels, more confusion" [comment #8, comment #11, comment #13] * Ed has strongly stated that unwritten rules are bad [comment #10]
The positions seem clear: * Ed, Kenn, Christian, and the Modeling PMC (EKCM) believe that these sub-component newsgroups are necessary because they address different audiences in sufficient volume that their presence in a unified newsgroup would overwhelm other topics in the unified newsgroup. EKCM further believe that requiring a change is dictatorial and should not be done. * The EMO believes that sub- and sub-sub-level newsgroups is contrary to our policies and that merged/unified newsgroups are generally a better solution.
Now, my thoughts, in three sections:
Part 1: Multiple Newsgroups Let's consider the two ridiculous end-points: (one) having a single newsgroup for all Eclipse projects and discussions, and (infinite) having a different newsgroup for each separate Eclipse-related topic thread. Both are obviously bogus, but for different reasons: the newsgroup in (one) would be too cluttered for anyone to extract useful information and (infinite) would require too many separate subscription decisions to be useful. Thus the optimal number of newsgroups is somewhere in the middle.
The EMO has chosen "one newsgroup per project plus additional newsgroups for very busy topics" as the balance. We've done so not because "having additional newsgroups is somehow a major inconvenience to the foundation itself" [comment #10] (obviously the IT burden of additional newsgroups is minor), but rather because we are interested in the visibility the Foundation provides to the Member companies, i.e., how many communication channels do the Members need to subscribe to in order to monitor the areas they are interested in? The Foundation exists to serve both masters: both the Projects and the Membership. What is optimal for one group may not be optimal for the other - our policies attempt to balance both.
Part 2: Who Determines Multiple Newsgroups In the discussion above, EKCM believe that the component leads should decide when a new newsgroup should be created, e.g., "Kenn's and Christian's opinions and their user community seem to carry far less weight relative to an apparently far more important overriding unwritten policiy. That doesn't seem right for a public foundation." [comment #10] and "In the end I think the policiy should be that if the community is well served by having a newsgroup, it should have one. Kenn and Christian are the best folks to speak to how to serve their community best" [comment #10] ... While I do not argue with EKCM about their user community, I'll point out that (a) the Foundation serves not only the UML sub-component users and developers - it serves the entire Eclipse community includes the other projects, the membership, and the larger eco-system. Eclipse Projects are, to be blunt, not allowed to make locally optimal, but globaly sub-optimal decisions (consider an example from licensing: a number of projects would love to use ANTLR, a decision that would be locally optimal for the projects, but globally sub-optimal given that package's licensing issues).
The decision about creating multiple newsgroups for a project resides with the EMO and can be appealed to the Board if necessary.
Part 3: UML2 OCL, UML2 UML, and UML2 Tools as components The final issue is that "UML2 OCL, UML2 UML, and UML2 Tools are separately downloadable subcomponents of MDT, with potentially different user communities" [comment #4] which is one indication that they are, effectively, separate projects. So they should _be_ separate projects. I anticipate that the Board will soon require them to be separate projects based on the revised Development Process (see paragraph one of http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Development_Process_2006_Revision_Final#Structure_and_Organization). When these components become the separate Eclipse Projects that they really are, then they will be entitled to separate newsgroups.
Solution: Given the membership visibility issues in (1), the policies of (2), and the sub-project structure issues of (3), the best solution is to convert these Components into Projects. Should the Modeling PMC schedule Creation Reviews they will necessarily consider the rationale for the community structure they prefer and the membership will become appraised of this reasoning by the public Review process. Should the Modeling PMC move promptly on this issue, it seems reasonable to leave these controversial newsgroups active until the proper Project structures are created.

(In reply to comment #16)
Dear Bjorn,
Now I am confused.
I understand your general presentation of the cons and pro, but for me the situation is less clear after your answer, because the notions of projects, components and sub-components may not be completely defined. Probably my comprehension of the Eclipse structure is not correct here.
The discussion started by a technical problem about newsgroups organization but now it seems to focus more on a general management problem now. This may be only because there is some overloading of the notion of "project". But I am not sure it is only a terminological problem.
Let me summarize the situation as I see it in the following presentation.
I will use the particular illustration of the Eclipse Modeling Project as currently presented on the page: http://www.eclipse.org/modeling/
We have there the concepts of:
"TopLevelProject" (example EMP, The Eclipse Modeling Project itself).
"StandardProject" (examples: GMF, GMT, UML2).
"Component" (examples: ATL, EODM).
"SubComponent" (example OCL, UML2Tools).
"NewsGroup" (examples: eclipse.modeling, eclipse.modeling.gmf, eclipse.modeling.gmt eclipse.modeling.gmt.amw, eclipse.modeling.m2t eclipse.modeling.mdt, eclipse.modeling.mdt.eodm eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2, eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.ocl,eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.tools).
"DomainArea" (examples: "Abstract Syntax Development", "Concrete Syntax Development", "Model Development Tools", "Model Transformation", "Model Integration", "Technology and Research").
Between these concepts, the following relations hold: A "TopLevel project" is composed of "StandardProjects". A "StandardProject" belongs to only one "TopLevelProject". A "StandardProject" may have status "created" or "in creation". A StandardProject is composed of "Components" ... A "Component" is composed of "SubComponents" ... A "NewsGroup" is associated to a "TopLevelProject", "StandardProject", "Component", "SubComponent". The name of a "NewsGroup" corresponds to the containment hierarchy of "TopLevelProject", "StandardProject", "Component", "SubComponent".
A "StandardProject" is associated to a "DomainArea". (This has no strong semantic implication it is like the grouping of "Smalltalk methods" under various "protocols") Let's thus forget about this in the context of the current discussion.
The problem started from the technical difficulties to deal with NewsGroups with a four-segment name (e.g. eclipse.modeling.gmt.amw) or five segment name (e.g. eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.ocl).
Then it was said that four-segmeent names were OK but five-segment names were impossible to handle for technical reasons.
Since four-segment names correspond to Components and five segment names correspond to SubComponents, I believed that the situation was under control since it could be possible to promote some Components as StandardProjects and to get rid of SubComponents in the EMP context.
But your answer seems to raise more fundamental questions, that needs now to be addressed. Apparently you suggest allowing only Newsgroup associated to StandardProjects, which is quite a radical decision. I do not see how to implement such a decision in the context of GMT. I anticipate problems in other EMP projects as well if this decision is implemented.
Mainly what you suggest is that a newsgroup should be associated to a StandardProject only and that all Components (or SubComponents) of this project should share the same NewsGroup. The experience we have in GMT shows that this does not work. We have experimented several solutions: - Asking people that prefix their questions and answers with the component name in bracket like [VIATRA2], [MOFScript], [oAW]. This does not seem to be a feasible solution when the component gathers some significant user community. It may however be a good transitory solution in the initial stage of a component lifecycle. - Using an external newsgroup. For example the ATL external Yahoo mailing list has received more than 2000 posts since January 2005. We consider this as bad Eclipse practice and plans were being made to migrate this to an Eclipse newsgroup before your mail.
What we cannot realistically do is to transform all GMT Components into StandardProjects for a lot of reasons. One of them is related to the nature of GMT which is a research incubator project, where successful components may migrate to other more industrially-finalized StandardProjects.
For me the best solution would be the status quo, with may be the suppression of the SubComponent concept (i.e. giving Component status to all SubComponents). At the project level it should be possible to estimate when a Component needs a separate own newsgroup. This should not be systematic, but possible. May be the TopLevel PMC should be in charge of the creation of NewsGroups for all StandardProjects and Components in the associated Toplevel project.
Hope it will be possible to find a solution that would be acceptable to all. I understand this is a critical issue, not for technical reasons but because the lives of the Eclipse communities are organized around these Newsgroups.
Best regards,
Jean
PS: While answering, I wrote a complete class diagram for this situation and I intend to use it as a student exercise. Interesting problem. When you add additional classes, all the attributes and some OCL constraints, it turns out to be a relatively complex, but quite typical modeling example.
> Interesting discussion. It looks like we are experiencing the usual > Eclipse-related tension between two interests (the projects and the > membership). I see three solutions to this problem: > 1. no change > - members are confused about project/newsgroup structure > and this makes the EMO unhappy > 2. reduce the number of newsgroups to match the number of projects > - newsgroups are cluttered and this makes Modeling users and > leaders and the EMO unhappy > 3. increase the number of projects to match the number of newsgroups > - everyone is happy > Before I go into detail about #3, let me try to summarize what I've read so > far: > * eclipse.modeling.gmt.* and eclipse.modeling.mdt.* are the only places in the > newsgroup hierarchy that exceed [toplevel].[subproject] or > [toplevel].[subtopic] naming [comment #0] > * The EMO prefers one newsgroup per project but when a newsgroup gets > significant traffic on a particular topic, we open a newsgroup for that topic > [comment #3] > * Ed, Kenn, and Christian believe that when multiple newsgroup are deemed > necessary, "it seems quite inflexible of the foundation not to allow [them]" > [comment #7] > * The EMO has taken the position that "by design, a very low number of > newsgroups on our server -- and from the news user's perspective, I think > that's a good thing" because "more groups = more complexity, more options and > more channels, more confusion" [comment #8, comment #11, comment #13] > * Ed has strongly stated that unwritten rules are bad [comment #10] > The positions seem clear: > * Ed, Kenn, Christian, and the Modeling PMC (EKCM) believe that these > sub-component newsgroups are necessary because they address different audiences > in sufficient volume that their presence in a unified newsgroup would overwhelm > other topics in the unified newsgroup. EKCM further believe that requiring a > change is dictatorial and should not be done. > * The EMO believes that sub- and sub-sub-level newsgroups is contrary to our > policies and that merged/unified newsgroups are generally a better solution. > Now, my thoughts, in three sections: > Part 1: Multiple Newsgroups > Let's consider the two ridiculous end-points: (one) having a single newsgroup > for all Eclipse projects and discussions, and (infinite) having a different > newsgroup for each separate Eclipse-related topic thread. Both are obviously > bogus, but for different reasons: the newsgroup in (one) would be too cluttered > for anyone to extract useful information and (infinite) would require too many > separate subscription decisions to be useful. Thus the optimal number of > newsgroups is somewhere in the middle. > The EMO has chosen "one newsgroup per project plus additional newsgroups for > very busy topics" as the balance. We've done so not because "having additional > newsgroups is somehow a major inconvenience to the foundation itself" [comment > #10] (obviously the IT burden of additional newsgroups is minor), but rather > because we are interested in the visibility the Foundation provides to the > Member companies, i.e., how many communication channels do the Members need to > subscribe to in order to monitor the areas they are interested in? The > Foundation exists to serve both masters: both the Projects and the Membership. > What is optimal for one group may not be optimal for the other - our policies > attempt to balance both. > Part 2: Who Determines Multiple Newsgroups > In the discussion above, EKCM believe that the component leads should decide > when a new newsgroup should be created, e.g., "Kenn's and Christian's opinions > and their user community seem to carry far less weight relative to an > apparently far more important overriding unwritten policiy. That doesn't seem > right for a public foundation." [comment #10] and "In the end I think the > policiy should be that if the community is well served by having a newsgroup, > it should have one. Kenn and Christian are the best folks to speak to how to > serve their community best" [comment #10] ... While I do not argue with EKCM > about their user community, I'll point out that (a) the Foundation serves not > only the UML sub-component users and developers - it serves the entire Eclipse > community includes the other projects, the membership, and the larger > eco-system. Eclipse Projects are, to be blunt, not allowed to make locally > optimal, but globaly sub-optimal decisions (consider an example from licensing: > a number of projects would love to use ANTLR, a decision that would be locally > optimal for the projects, but globally sub-optimal given that package's > licensing issues). > The decision about creating multiple newsgroups for a project resides with the > EMO and can be appealed to the Board if necessary. > Part 3: UML2 OCL, UML2 UML, and UML2 Tools as components > The final issue is that "UML2 OCL, UML2 UML, and UML2 Tools are separately > downloadable subcomponents of MDT, with potentially different user communities" > [comment #4] which is one indication that they are, effectively, separate > projects. So they should _be_ separate projects. I anticipate that the Board > will soon require them to be separate projects based on the revised Development > Process (see paragraph one of > http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Development_Process_2006_Revision_Final#Structure_and_Organization). > When these components become the separate Eclipse Projects that they really > are, then they will be entitled to separate newsgroups. > Solution: > Given the membership visibility issues in (1), the policies of (2), and the > sub-project structure issues of (3), the best solution is to convert these > Components into Projects. Should the Modeling PMC schedule Creation Reviews > they will necessarily consider the rationale for the community structure they > prefer and the membership will become appraised of this reasoning by the public > Review process. Should the Modeling PMC move promptly on this issue, it seems > reasonable to leave these controversial newsgroups active until the proper > Project structures are created.

We intentionally limited the number of projects in Modeling, for a variety of reasons touched upon in this thread.
Going back to my earlier comment #6, why not stick to the 4-level structure by eliminating the nesting of components under the uml2 component (no subcomponents in MDT)? This appears to satisfy the new process guidelines, and we've agreed that Components of sufficient interest are worthy of having their own newsgroup.
That said, I'm not sure I follow the logic that the EMO favors the creation of distinct projects and respective newsgroups (and the additional administrative overhead of projects) over the support of component-level newsgroups.
Finally, if the characteristic of having a separately downloadable component is justification for having a separate project, we'll need to modify more than the Modeling project's structure.

Wow. At this point I'm thinking Rich has the right idea. Perhaps we can "meet in the middle" - assuming the EMO is OK with having component-level newsgroups (which it was at one point), then we can resolve this issue by promoting UML2 OCL, UML2 UML, and UML2 Tools to be components (as opposed to subcomponents of the UML2 component). Is it safe to assume that this kind of "promotion" is something that can be approved by the Modeling PMC?
This would result in the following newsgroup migration:
eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.ocl -> eclipse.modeling.mdt.ocl eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.uml -> eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.tools -> eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2tools
Note that since UML2 Tools will provide tooling that incorporates both OCL and UML, I think it should retain "uml2" in its name (instead of just "uml").
Would it be possible to rename the corresponding components in Bugzilla, and to adjust the mailing lists accordingly?

Actually, it may make more sense (less churn, etc., since an eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2 newsgroup seems to already have appeared) to use this mapping:
eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.uml -> eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2

I spoke to Rich (Modeling PMC) today and we've come to these conclusions:
1. The MDT project comprises multiple components which were previously acting as sub-projects by releasing independently. The Modeling PMC and MDT leadership is working towards a single release for all the MDT components, thus the MDT components will qualify as components even under the new rules.
2. The EMO provides newsgroups to top-projects and sub-projects.
3. The EMO provides splits newsgroups if one topic so overwhelms the rest of the newsgroup. We believe that the UML2 and OCL topics in the eclipse.modeling.mdt newsgroup qualifies for a separate topic-centric newsgroup. We will entertain other topic-centric requests but, in conjunction with the Modeling PMC, do not see any other topics needing sub-groups at this time.
4. The Modeling PMC will work with the GMT project to figure out the right newsgroup strategy for that project (using these guidelines).
Thus these newsgroup should stay: eclipse.modeling.gmt.amw eclipse.modeling.gmt.modisco eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2 eclipse.modeling.mdt.ocl eclipse.modeling.mdt
And these newsgroups should be closed and archived: eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.ocl (becomes eclipse.modeling.mdt.ocl) eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.uml eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.tools eclipse.modeling.mdt.xsd
Denis - are you ok with this?

Bjorn, I think it makes most sense to retain a separate newsgroup for components that are separately built and installable, have separate release versions, and have distinct user communities. Thus, I plead for the following structure:
EODM next release version: 2.0 newsgroup: eclipse.modeling.mdt.eodm (status quo) mailing list: mdt-eodm.dev (status quo) user community: DEVELOPERS of tools based on ODM
OCL next release version: 1.1 newsgroup: eclipse.modeling.mdt.ocl (replaces eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.ocl) mailing list: mdt-ocl.dev (replaces mdt-uml2-ocl.dev) user community: DEVELOPERS of tools based on OCL
UML2 next release version: 2.1 newsgroup: eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2 (replaces eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.uml) mailing list: mdt-uml2.dev (replaces mdt-uml2-uml.dev) user community: DEVELOPERS of tools based on UML 2.x
UML2 Tools next release version: 1.0 newsgroup: eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2tools (replaces eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.tools) mailing list: mdt-uml2tools.dev (replaces mdt-uml2-tools.dev) user community: USERS of tools based on UML 2 umbrella of standards (OCL, UML, DI)
XSD next release version: 2.3 newsgroup: eclipse.modeling.mdt.xsd (status quo) mailing list: mdt-xsd.dev (status quo) user community: developers of tools based on XSD

Bjorn,
Exactly in the same spirit than Kenn, I would argue to the necessity of having at least some components with separate newsgroups in GMT (not all, but some).
This should not be systematic, and could apply to the most active components, but I do not see the possibility to run GMT as a research incubator project with only one newsgroup for many very different topics.
Best regards,
Jean
(In reply to comment #22) > Bjorn, I think it makes most sense to retain a separate newsgroup for > components that are separately built and installable, have separate release > versions, and have distinct user communities. Thus, I plead for the following > structure: > EODM > next release version: 2.0 > newsgroup: eclipse.modeling.mdt.eodm (status quo) > mailing list: mdt-eodm.dev (status quo) > user community: DEVELOPERS of tools based on ODM > OCL > next release version: 1.1 > newsgroup: eclipse.modeling.mdt.ocl (replaces eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.ocl) > mailing list: mdt-ocl.dev (replaces mdt-uml2-ocl.dev) > user community: DEVELOPERS of tools based on OCL > UML2 > next release version: 2.1 > newsgroup: eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2 (replaces eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.uml) > mailing list: mdt-uml2.dev (replaces mdt-uml2-uml.dev) > user community: DEVELOPERS of tools based on UML 2.x > UML2 Tools > next release version: 1.0 > newsgroup: eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2tools (replaces > eclipse.modeling.mdt.uml2.tools) > mailing list: mdt-uml2tools.dev (replaces mdt-uml2-tools.dev) > user community: USERS of tools based on UML 2 umbrella of standards (OCL, UML, > DI) > XSD > next release version: 2.3 > newsgroup: eclipse.modeling.mdt.xsd (status quo) > mailing list: mdt-xsd.dev (status quo) > user community: developers of tools based on XSD

Kenn, Jean, you need to discuss this with the Modeling PMC - as I said I phoned up Rich and explained the EMO's concerns and he explained the PMC's concerns and we came to a conclusion. I'd rather not step on the PMC toes...

Well, my original request was to only close three groups. The net result of this discussion appears to be closing four groups and creating a new one. I'm confused but I won't argue.

bug.short_desc: move aspectj nature from ui to core plugin

long_desc.thetext: Currently the aspectj nature is defined within the ui plugin. It would make more sense for it to be defined in the core plugin in the same way that the builder is.

Agreed, although it's tricky to move because of the migration issues. We want the transition from old nature to new nature to be transparent, without a performance overhead after migration. We also want migrated projects to still work properly on older versions of AJDT which don't define the new nature.
As discussed, the current thinking is to define the new nature to behave like the old nature, and for the old nature to no longer have any effect (except possibly the "AJ" image decorator on the project). The core builder can then check for the absence of the new builder whenever the project is built, and add it if required (a nature check is almost zero in performance terms). The old nature will not be removed, so that the project can still be used with older versions of AJDT.

Although it makes more sense to define the nature in core, and we've established a way such a migration could be handled, there doesn't currently appear to be a compelling reason to make the move. So given the work involved and the risk of migration problems, I'm closing this as resolve > later - until such time as there is a compelling reason.

bug.short_desc: [Memory View] Leak of memory retrieval objects

long_desc.thetext:
Created an attachment (id=55767) Patch to fix memory leak
Assuming that the tree viewer should be empty when a debug target is terminated, the fix is to NOT save viewer state when the tree viewer is empty.
When the debug session is terminated, the viewer state of the terminated target is removed from fViewerState. When switching selection from the terminated debug session to a live one, the tree viewer is empty. As a result, the terminated debug target does not get added back to fViewerState.

Darin,
I would like to target this for 3.2.2. As Ken has indicated, this causes leak at a significant rate and should be fixed for 3.2.2.
This should no longer be a problem for 3.3 as the tree view pane will get migrated to use TreeModelViewer. Viewer states are handled by the viewer using mementos. I will confirm this when doing the migration.
Ken, it would be great if you can verify that this fixes your problem.
Thanks... Samantha

Samantha, wouldn't it be safer to only perform the state saving if the target is not terminated, rather than relying on ordering of events (which seems fragile). Is it possible to get the IDebugTarget adapter from the IMemoryRetrieval (or some other way to get the target), and just test if the target is terminated?

The issue with checking if the target is terminated is that IMemoryBlockRetrieval is not tied to a debug target in any way. IMemoryBlockRetrieval is not a debug element and there is no specification requiring a client to provide a debug target adapter for an IMemoryBlockRetrieval object. If the IMemoryBlockRetrieval object does not provide an adapter for IDebugTarget, this approach will not work and the leak will still be there because we cannot determine if the target is terminated.
A safer approach is to do both. i.e. try to get an adapter to a debug target and check if it's terminated. If this fails, then we check if the tree viewer is empty.
I will provide a new patch.
Thanks... Samantha

Created an attachment (id=55856) patch2 to fix leak
I am changing the way we are saving and restoring viewer state. The old way holds on to model object and uses the memory block retrieval object as key to a hashtable. Since we don't have dispose event from the model object, we cannot reliable determine when the viewer state of a memory block retrieval object should be removed from the hashtable.
The new patch mirrors how the Variables View saves and restores viewer state. It uses indices instead of the actual objects to save and restore viewer states. The hashcode of the memory block retrieval object is used as the key to a MRUMap. The map has max size of 20 viewer states and will remove the viewer state least used from teh map when it is full.
Changes: MemoryBlocksTreeViewPane - saves and restores viewer state by indices and hashcode MemoryViewTreeViewer - need to try to restore viewer state when update is completed VariablesView - moved MRUMap to a separate file for the Memory View to reuse MRUMap - new file

Darin,
Please review patch2. The patch is for R3_2_maintenance stream.
Thanks... Samantha
Released patch to 3.2.2.
Verified.

bug.short_desc: Generating the Homepage Statically vs Dynamically

long_desc.thetext:
Denis and I were talking this morning about changing the way the main page is displayed to save on CPU cycles / SQL queries of the server.
After the changes to the Most Active / Top Rated Plugins List are made. The home page will have a total of 13 SQL queries when generated. On Average the homepage is displayed over 10000 times a day, thats 130,000 SQL queries.
Solution would be to WGET the index.php file every X minutes and save it in the web server as index.html. Say we set this to be every 5 minutes. Thats 3744 Queries a day. And content updates would only be delayed by 5 minutes at most.
Index.php would still exist and work but saving these cycles on teh CPU and SQL server will go along way in the long run.
Correction 13,000 not 130,000

+1
Not only will this reduce some load on the servers, but it will definitely improve the load time of the epic homepage (it will load faster).
For instance, from an external computer, loading the HTML only (no javascript/images) for the http://www.eclipseplugincentral.com/ homepage (dynamically) takes, on average (after 40 samples) about 1.0 - 1.3 seconds:
$ time wget -C off --delete-after http://www.eclipseplugincentral.com/ 10:31:53 (440.53 KB/s) - `index.html' saved [34,293]
real 0m1.179s user 0m0.010s sys 0m0.018s
From the same computer, accessing basically the same HTML from a static, pre-generated HTML file takes less than 0.2 second.
$ time wget -C off --delete-after http://www.eclipseplugincentral.com/test.htm 10:30:03 (339.67 KB/s) - `test.htm' saved [34,296/34,296]
real 0m0.169s user 0m0.009s sys 0m0.011s
Besides the 5 minutes delay on content are there any other negatives? If not then I vote +1

bug.short_desc: Test log viewer - Overview - Verdict List problems

long_desc.thetext:
Here are some problems that I found using the Overview page from "Test log viewer" (which is actually an editor, this seems to a naming problem):
1. The Verdict Summary although draws the attention in the first place doesn't give a quick look of the overall verdict, to find that the user has to check which percentage is larger or look at the "Common Properties"->Verdict entry or look at the Verdict List where first time the overall verdict type is shown there. Would be good to have a visual (graphical) cue that can quickly tells us the overall verdict.
2. The Verdict List shows the last 20 verdicts which is good, although the label used for the links doesn't give any information about where the verdict was generated, I think it would be much better to also show the "Element description" of the verdict element (see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=54484&action=view for an example from Bug 165785).
The overall verdict event is the last one and that will not be directly accessible from overview if we have more then 20 verdicts of that type, would be good to have a separate link just for the overall verdict which could be accessed through the visual cue proposed in problem 1.
marius this seems like a samll enhancement request. Please work with Paul to move it to 4.4

I agree, I meant it to be an enhancement.
Paul please change the priority accordingly.
Another quick improvement can be done on the Events page, initially by using more meaningfully labels in the "Events" tree (use the content shown in "Element description" plus some prefix/postfix where needed) and later using a filtering capability in that tree with options like show only "invocation" type nodes and somehow combine the messages in the "Text" field, that way we can quickly look at the results without the need to expand 3 levels to see the error/failure messages.
Reassign to Bianca. Bianca handles Test Log issues.

These are valid improvement's for the Test Log Viewer.
Adjusting priority to include as a 4.4 candidate.

(In reply to comment #2) > I agree, I meant it to be an enhancement. > > Paul please change the priority accordingly. > > Another quick improvement can be done on the Events page, initially by using > more meaningfully labels in the "Events" tree (use the content shown in > "Element description" plus some prefix/postfix where needed) and later using a > filtering capability in that tree with options like show only "invocation" type > nodes and somehow combine the messages in the "Text" field, that way we can > quickly look at the results without the need to expand 3 levels to see the > error/failure messages. >
The Event labels are extensible. There's an extension point where extenders can use to customize the icon and display text of the events. There is a default label provider if such an extender doesn't exist. Based on the event type, the default label provider displays different attributes of the event. For example, it uses label attribute for verdict events and the name of the interactionFragment for loop events.
For filtering, there is an existing enhancement request on this: bug 108527. Before that's implemented, the test log viewer Search function (bug 89341) can be used to help get a list of one or more specific types of event.

Updating target to future as requested by the PMC.
Enhancements are targeted to future if not in plan for the current release.
Correcting priority since not a 4.5 candidate enhancement (see http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/development/bugzilla.html).

bug.short_desc: Standard Project Build: Include paths not passed to make(file)

long_desc.thetext:
I just spent an age poking around in a standard build project wondering why the include paths that I specified in "Properties: C/C++ Include Paths & Symbols" are not passed to the makefile - despite having clicked "Export". Then I discovered the following interesting link:
http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.tools.cdt/msg08788.html
The GUI seems thereby to be suggesting a functionality that it is not delivering, and is thus at least very misleading. Conversely, if the include paths are really supposed to be passed to the makefile, then this does not seem to be happening. Could you provide some feedback here please?

bug.short_desc: [javadoc] Should not report ambiguous on method with parameterized types as parameters

long_desc.thetext:
On bug 165701 comment 1 test case, compiler should not warn the ambiguous method in javadoc comment as javadoc tool does not report any...
Note that as there's no way to distinguish the two methods with raw types, it seems that generated doc always uses the last method for the link.
Created an attachment (id=54495) Proposed patch

Philippe, May you review my change in Scope: set closestMatch for ambiguous method when all most specific methods are equals in mostSpecificMethodBinding (return at the end). Do you think we can also set it on other returns in this method?

Released for 3.3 M4 in HEAD stream.
Philippe, I finally removed the change on Scope as it had undesirable side effects on some compiler tests... Closest match was not really necessary to fix this issue but perhaps it would be good to think about it in the future?
Verified for 3.3M4 with I20061212-0010.

bug.short_desc: Toolbar inconsistent between workspaces

long_desc.thetext:
I ran into a problem recording an AGR test case and realized that the toolBar in the Log View (after importing a Log file) sometimes has the 'Properties' Item as the last Item and sometimes has the 'Go To Page' Item as the last item.
Specifically:
1) Open a new 4.3 (200611160100B) workspace. 2) Import a Log File 3) Switch to Profiling and Logging Perspective >Log View 4) Notice that the local toolBar contains the 'Go To Page' item as the last Item.
5) Launch an Eclipse Application to a new workspace never used before from your original workspace 6) Import the same Log File 7) Swicth To Profiling and Logging Perspective> Log View 8) Notice that the 'Properties' Item is the last in the local ToolBar.
This causes a problem when recording an AGR test becasue when it launches a new workspace the toolbar items are out of order compared to where it was recorded.

I cannot reproduce the problem with both IBM and Sun JVM 1.4.2 and 1.5. IBM_1.4.2_SR6 IBM_1.5_SR3_1002 SUN_1.4.2_12 SUN_1.5.0_08
I will try it on other machine, Can you also verify on other machine?

Liz, I cannot reproduce the problem on another machine. Can you confirm the driver and steps to reproduce the problem, also please try to run on another machine to verify its consistence. And reopen bug as necessary. THX.
I tried to verify on another machine but could not reproduce the defect. I am satisfied leaving it as WONTFIX.
update target
Dave has reported seeing this in 4.4i1 workbench.
Changing target to i2 because it is not a serious problem that needs to be addressed in i1.
Updated sizing

I tried this using TPTP-4.4.0-200703270100 and a CBE XML Log (C:\eclipse\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.hyades.logging.parsers_4.3.100.v200703230934\config\XML\CommonBaseEvent\v1.0.1\example.log) and could not reproduce the problem.
Adding Alex to the CC list as he ran into this when launching an AGR test today.
This is nice to have from AC perspective.

bug.short_desc: [Sync View] Allow to open several compares in parallel

long_desc.thetext:
N20061124-0010
Allowing to open the compare editor from the Synchronize view in the background is really neat but currently I am restricted to one editor. I would like to click on several files and let them fetch in the background.
This would allow me - who often has slow connectivity - to click on all the changes and do some other work while this is loaded in the background. This is especially helpful for looking at all the incoming changes in the morning.
I'll try to investigate this in M5.
There is now an option on the Team preference page to reuse editors. Turing it off will allow multiple editors to be opened in parallel.
Michael, can it be done using something like Ctrl-Double-Click?

It is tricky because Eclipse has an open strategy that can be configured to be either single or double click and the open event does not contain any information about the original SWT event. This means that you would need to hardcode the behavior into the sync view as a double click listener. The problem with this is that is doesn't offer the user any tailorability. So, in summary, it is not a trivial fix so I wouldn't want to piggyback it on this request. If you feel this would be useful, I would recommend entering a new enhancement request.
The reuse vs. open in same editor plus the ability to let the user override its current preference is also discussed in bug 168379.
Verified using I20070123-1715.
